mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rattans (canes) in India. A Monographic Revision

nomenclature.name: Calamus kingianus
nomenclature.author: Becc.
nomenclature.citation: Ann. Roy. Bot. Gard. Calcutta 11:197. 1908 and Appendix PI. 53. 1913.

div.p: A slender cluster-forming climber; stem with leafsheath 10 - 12 mm in diameter. Leaves ecirrate to 70 cm long; leafsheath with slender flagellum and distinct knee, armed outside with closely packed short, straight spines; ocrea hairy, caducous; petiole about 16cm long, armed all along with solitary claws; leaflets about 12 in number; basal leaflets paired, alternate, middle leaflets opposite, distantly disposed, 20-26 cm long, 3-3.5 cm wide at middle, 5-nerved; uppermost leaflets digitate, shorter than others; terminal leaflets connate at base. Male inflorescence rigid, simply branched; primary bracts tubular, elongate, closely sheathing, flattened on both sides, obliquely truncate at mouth, armed with straight spines intermingled with short hooks; axial part of male inflorescence armed with small scattered hooks: partial inflorescences with longer terminal rachillae and 4-5 pendulous rachillae on each side below; rachillae 4- 9 cm long, attached on distinct cushion just outside the mouth of the respective basal bracts; male flowers ovate, acute, 5 mm long, 20 - 22 in number on each side of the rachilla; calyx more or less cylindrical with 3-broadly triangular; acute lobes; corolla twice longer than calyx. Female inflorescence twice branched; partial inflorescences delicate, with a few spines scattered on the tubular primary bracts; first order branches distinctly adnate to main axis; female rachillae 10-12 in number, alternate, attached above the mouth of the respective basal bracts. Fruit globose, about 1 cm in diameter, with small stigmatic remains, sessile; fruit scales greenish-yellow in colour, margins deep brown, shallowly channelled at middle. Seed not examined.
This thin stemmed bushy rattan prefers to grow prostrate on moist alluvium. Infrequent in its natural habitat.
The cane is thin and delicate and therefore has no commercial value. Fruit pulp is eaten by the local people of Kokoi Reserve Forest, North Lakhimpore, Assam.
Assam: Tangeli Bam, Oct. 1892, Prain's Collector 89 (CAL); North Lakhimpore, Kokoi Reserve Forest, 22.11.1957, Panigrahi 397 (CAL) ; Nowgong from Guahaty, 29.9.1957, Rao 9721 (CAL).
